title: ‘A puppy cured me after I was crushed between a bus and an armoured car'

As part of his role in the Royal Air Force Volunteer Reserve, John Lewis often visited schools.

But it was during a routine visit to a London school one Friday afternoon back in June 2004 that his life changed irrevocably.

He was outside showing pupils an armoured personnel carrier (an armoured, military vehicle designed to transport personnel and equipment in combat zones), when the school bus reversed into the car park and didn’t see him.

Within seconds, John, now 43, was crushed between the bus and the troop carrier.

‘I couldn’t breathe,’ he says.

‘It happened so quickly, I was in shock, I fell to the ground and all I could see was the double wheels at the back of the bus – I knew I had to get out of the way because if the bus reversed again it would kill me.’

Despite multiple injuries – a shattered pelvis and hip and broken leg – John managed to crawl five to six metres on his elbows to get out of the way of the wheels.

An ambulance arrived and John was rushed to Whittington Hospital in London.

‘My first thought was, “Will I be able to walk again?”’ he recalls.

‘None of the doctors could answer that. My bones were broken in so many places that an operation wasn’t possible.'

'I had to remain in traction while my bones rebuilt themselves.’

John’s injuries were so severe, the doctors couldn’t operate until six months later.

He had 11 operations in total and it was two years before he could walk again.

Shortly after he was discharged from hospital, he received a visit from an old friend, Anna.

They had met in the Cadet Forces – she had heard about the accident and wanted to check he was OK.

‘John was still on crutches at the time,’ says Anna, 34.

‘He was in quite a good place, focusing on getting better.'

'But I realised he wasn’t going to cope when he offered me a glass of water, I took one sip and it was full of washing-up liquid – he hadn’t been able to rinse it properly.’

John was off work for 18 months after the accident, then returned to work in a part-time office role on a Zimmer frame.

He was living on his own and didn’t have any carers, so Anna started helping out with things like cooking meals and washing up.

‘We had the same interests, we were company for each other and got on really well,’ she says.

‘We’d sit for hours and hours chatting.’

As the months went on, they fell in love.

They married in 2009, between having their two children – Kieran, now 14, and Summer, now nine.

Although John improved physically and was awarded compensation, he couldn’t get over the trauma of what had happened.

The bus driver was convicted with nine points on his licence and kept his job, whereas John couldn’t go back to work for two years and changed career twice due to stress.

‘My mind was still on edge,’ he says.

‘I was scared of large vehicles and the sound of a reverse beeping noise – I would have flashbacks and sometimes be sick.’

He was also terrified of crowds and didn’t want to leave home.

‘Before the accident, I was out of the house all the time,’ he says.

‘I loved working with young people, I loved working in sport and outdoors.'

'But because of my injuries, I couldn’t handle the physicality of going for long walks any more.’

John volunteered with St John Ambulance and spent five years in the ambulance service as an emergency care assistant, but the irregular hours only increased his anxiety.

‘My shift would often overrun and I’d be late getting home to Anna and the kids, and that shot me to pieces,’ he says.

‘I would be massively stressed at work all day in case I didn’t finish on time, and if I finished late I’d take it out on the controllers and blame them.'

' It was too much – I couldn’t live with the pressure.'

‘I also had a real problem with anyone who had a job and, in my opinion, wasn’t doing it properly.'

'If a supermarket didn’t have a particular loaf of bread on the shelf, I’d start arguing with the manager; if my mobile phone didn’t work or if the internet went down for 10 minutes, I’d have large verbal arguments with the customer services agent.'

'I felt people should be held accountable for their actions.’

Anna recalls being in a shop where the special offer had been put on the wrong shelf.

‘We then proceeded to spend an hour and a half in the store complaining to the manager that it was misleading because we’d bought the wrong bottle of squash,’ she says.

‘The squash was only about £1 – I think that was the point where I said to John, “You need to go and find help.”’

Concerned, Anna encouraged John to get support and he had 16 weeks of therapy.

His behaviour was put down to the fact he felt so let down by life, and the fact the bus driver had not been held accountable, so John wanted everybody else to be held accountable for their actions.

Although it helped him understand his behaviour, it didn’t provide a cure.

‘I never really asked for help,’ he says.

‘I always justified my actions and my argument and therefore I didn’t feel like there was anything wrong.’

The family left London and moved to the countryside in North Devon in an attempt to live a quieter life.

But when Anna started working longer hours, John’s anxiety got worse.

‘It was wonderful to be out of the city, but any time Anna was away from home, I started to get really anxious –. I couldn’t relax,’ he says.

‘My mind would run all over the place.'

'I’d be so stressed by the time she came home, it got to the point where Anna didn’t want to go out because she didn’t want to see me upset.'

'Our relationship started to break down – I was making her life hell.’

As the years rolled on, John’s mental health deteriorated.

He suffered from depression, began to self-harm and had suicidal thoughts.

‘I felt like I was letting everybody down,’ he says.

‘It was beginning to take over my life, but I didn’t know what to do.'

‘I tried to hide it from the kids, but they became aware of it over time.'

'Both children now have anxiety and have spoken about not being sure how Dad is.'

'They are much more understanding after reading a book called Why Is Dad So Mad? – a story about a military dad with PTSD written especially for kids.’

John had counselling and various types of therapy and was diagnosed with post-traumatic stress disorder (PTSD), but none of the treatment seemed to help.

Then last year, at a Combat Stress hospital (a place to help veterans’ mental health), he was introduced to the therapeutic power of animals and a doctor told him a puppy might help with his anxiety.

‘I’d never thought of it as a mechanism for coping before,’ he says.

‘We already had a family dog, a crossbreed called Bolt, but he was old and set in his ways.'

'The doctor explained puppies can help manage stress and focus the mind.’

In May 2019, they enlisted the help of a four-legged companion – a black Labrador pup called Gibson.

‘After just a few weeks, I could feel myself improving,’ explains John.

‘If I was feeling anxious, he would jump up on the sofa and sit on my chest and I found that really reassuring and comforting.'

'It doesn’t matter where I am, he’ll pin me down, hold me tight and it’s really helped with my anxiety.'

'We go out and play frisbee and I now look forward to going out for walks, whereas before I would always make excuses to stay in the house, which would make me feel worse – to say he’s changed my life is an understatement.’

Since John has been taking Gibson for walks three or four times a day, Anna has also noticed a difference.

‘Initially, John was so focused on medically getting better, I don’t think the long-term impact really hit him,’ she says.

‘Gibson has made a huge impact.'

'He has been a massive help and comfort to him – it has given him a focus and new lease of life.'

'Gibson is an incredible dog that adores John – he’s a fantastic companion.’

John is now taking part in Generation Pup, a groundbreaking study that tracks puppies through to adulthood to learn how their early experiences and environment affect their development.

John says, ‘I really enjoy watching my relationship with Gibson flourish and tracking this through the study, watching as his personality begins to grow and support me on my road back to mental health, which he is playing a big part of.'

'Gibson has done so much for me in a short space of time, I wanted to do something for him.’ ■

Generation Pup: The Facts

Generation Pup follows dogs over their lifetime to see how events or environments early in life influence their development as they get older.

The research also looks at why dogs develop problem behaviours and issues such as noise phobia and separation anxiety.

It is the largest study of dog health and welfare in a generation.

More than 3,000 dog owners have signed up so far and the aim is to have over 10,000.

Dogs Trust is calling on puppy owners of all breeds to take part (before the puppies are 16 weeks old).

New recruits receive an annual personalised report tracking their dog’s behaviour and development.

Generation Pup is funded by Dogs Trust, the UK’s largest dog welfare charity. CLICK HERE for more info.
description: After a life-changing accident, John Lewis's suffered with crippling PTSD – until a four-legged friend came to his rescue
